description: A back-formation from chemise (mistaken for a plural).

entries.meaning: A dance movement involving thrusting the shoulders back and forth alternately.
A dance that was popular in the 1920s.
An abnormal vibration, especially in the wheels of a vehicle.

verbs.description: shimmy (third-person singular simple present shimmies, present participle shimmying, simple past and past participle shimmied)

entries.meaning: (dance) To perform a shimmy (dance movement involving thrusting the shoulders back and forth alternately).
examples: She wondered would he think her awful, and try to get fresh if she shimmied. Fellows often did. But he was so cute. And a girl had to something about that, and if she didn't shimmy, she might do something worse.

entries.meaning: To climb something (e.g. a pole) gradually (e.g. using alternately one's arms then one's legs).
examples: The static made her dress shimmy up her leg.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To vibrate abnormally, as a broken wheel.
(intransitive, rare) To shake the body as if dancing the shimmy.
(intransitive, video games) To move across a narrow ledge, either by hanging from it or by strafing on it along the wall.
examples: Jump up to the ledge on your right and shimmy around the corner.
